body: Can you provide an example of code that caused this issue?

Well, it's happening everytime when querying database and not freeing results, no mather what the code is. mysql warning. "Use mysql_free_result to free result". I dont know for the others types or error with mysql. Only happening with mysql databases errors.

screen capture = http://www.flickr.com/photos/79969631@N02/7160235307/

For the because, I dont know why.
Older version of CodeIgniter will not produce this error.
When injecting the error in the view if the error_php.php file is not found, the error is "Use mysql_free_result to free result".
You can turn that specific warning off by turning mysql.trace_mode to Off in php.ini. But you can't expect it to work properly if a file is missing.

I have make a new install and I have juste written 3 files to remake the error. (Database + Config + Welcome controller)
Every CodeIgniter file is in the filepath. CI is completely stock.

PHP error trigger the error correctly and the file is found.
MySQL goes wrong... file nor found.

Part of the trace... This is a CI bug.

CI_Exceptions->show_php_error( $severity = 2, $message = 'Unknown: 1 result set(s) not freed. Use mysql_free_result to free result sets which were requested using mysql_query()', $filepath = 'Unknown', $line = 0 )

@websam101 Please just zip your base folder; Send to ckdarby+github@gmail.com & I'll make sure it isn't an environment issue on your box.

Cheers.

sent.
my.ini
php.ini
ci test - folder
ci test - db dump
Just forgot to delete the user_guide folder to save space and time... Sorry for this.
If you need something else like apache .confs just let me know.
It's almost stock, and in dev mode.
This bug only happen with CodeIgniter 2 +
From what I see in the screenshot - the only logical explanation is that `APPPATH` is either not defined or empty.

If I take and older version of CodeIgniter, there is no bug for both PHP and MySQL error messages or path.

On the 2+ branch and if I'm not wrong the 3.0 dev too...
If I have a PHP error, there is no bug.
If I have a MySQL error... there is something wrong with path yes.. but where ???

Is it in the command that call the error ?
I have not found the source yet. Time is missing a bit these days.
I guess we'll have to wait on @ckdarby to check on this.

I can not replicate this with the exact copy @websam101 sent me on any of my machines:

~Windows 7~
MySQL 5.5.20
Apache 2.2.10
PHP 5.3.10

~Ubuntu 11.04~
MySQL 5.1.62
Apache 2.2.17
PHP 5.3.6

~Ubuntu 12.04~
MySQL 5.5.22
Apache 2.2.22
PHP 5.3.10

Got the results without any warnings, can check [here](https://docs.google.com/file/d/0B_SJJN9g_C5jV3VjcDQzREg1eDA/edit)
Did you turn mysql.trace_mode to On? Just in case.
Oops, I turned mysql.trace_mode On & all hell broke lose exactly as he mentioned.
OK, reopening and will try to investigate myself some more later. Though, I still think this is an outside issue and not a CI bug.

GOTCHA !!!

Exceptions.php line 182 is the **default error handler** but the path does **not** provide the **full path**.
So when we have an error from **anywhere** from outside, the system could not find the file to include.

**Original**

``` PHP
include(APPPATH.'errors/error_php.php');
```

**Fix**

``` PHP
include(FCPATH.APPPATH.'errors/error_php.php');
```

For CI **2.1.0+** and **3.0dev**

Okay, now you've convinced me that it's a flaw in CI. :)

This fix is still not universal though - it's relying on the assumption that `APPPATH` is under the same directory as _index.php_. We'll have to think of something else.

We should also think of wether we should try to disable MySQL trace mode when the driver is initialized or adding `mysql_free_result()` to `CI_DB_mysql_result`'s destructor. Which one do you see as more appropriate?

I think that the full path must be injected before the defined APPPATH to prevent any PHP dependency error. (sendmail, database ...etc.)

I also like your idea of the mysql destructor, this could save some time inserting mysql_free_result() everywhere where a query is called.

Both are great.
